Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Robustness of Strategic Behavior to Misspecification of Agents' Beliefs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research in the theory of games with incomplete information. This branch of noncooperative game theory has a wide range of applications in Economics and other social sciences. Examples include the analysis of optimal taxation, auctions and procurement design, signaling models of the labor market, adverse selection models of trade and insurance markets, reputation and commitment in long-run relationships, credibility of monetary policies, and strategic trading in financial markets.

Previous research has established that the predictions made by game theory about behavior in these situations are quite sensitive to the assumptions made about the players' infinite hierarchies of beliefs. The PIs develop new methods to study this robustness problem. They evaluate the severity of the robustness problem by characterizing necessary and sufficient conditions for the strategic behavior of a given Harsanyi type to be approximated by the strategic behavior of (a sequence of) perturbed types. This amounts to providing a belief-based characterization of the strategic topology over types. The investigators also apply their characterization to a variety of questions concerning robustness to perturbations of higher-order beliefs, including genericity of common priors and of critical types, and the connections between robustness of strategic behavior and the notion of common p-belief.

The project will have broader impact because this branch of game theory is used to study applied problems in multiple domains, including Computer Science, and Biology. The PIs will be incorporating their research into graduate courses and will train graduate students in these new methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project concerns new research in the theory of games with incomplete information.  This branch of noncooperative game theory has a wide range of applications in Economics, including to optimal taxation, auctions and procurement design, signaling models of the labor market, adverse selection models of trade and insurance markets, reputation and commitment in long-run relationships, credibility of monetary policies, durable goods monopolies and strategic trading in financial markets.

Specifically, we evaluate the extent to which game theoretic solutions are sensitive to the modeler’s assumptions about the players’ information structures. Our findings in the project have been reported in four papers which are either published or conditionally accepted at top economics journals, which are listed as follows. 

 

(1) “Strategic impact of higher-order beliefs,” Yi-Chun Chen, Alfredo Di Tillio, Eduardo Faingold and Siyang Xiong, Review of Economic Studies, conditionally accepted.

(2) “The robust selection of rationalizability,” Yi-Chun Chen, Satoru Takahashi and Siyang Xiong, Journal of Economic Theory, Volume 151, p.448-475, May 2014 

(3) “The e-mail game phenomenon,” Yi-Chun Chen and Siyang Xiong, Games and Economic Behavior, Volume 80, p.147-156, July 2013

(4) “Genericity and robustness of full surplus extraction,” Yi-Chun Chen and Siyang Xiong, Econometrica, Volume 81, Issue 2, p.825-847, March 2013

 

In (1), we provide a full belief-based characterization of the strategic topology (Dekel, Fudenberg and Morris 2006), which becomes a fundamental tool for analysis on strategic impact of higher-order beliefs in various economic problems. Applying the ideas developed in (1) to two well-known economic games, we generalise the e-mail-game phenomenon (i.e., (3)), and characterize the robust selections in global games (i.e., (2)). Finally, in (4), we show the strategic impact of high-order beliefs in mechanism design problems, e.g., auction and procurement design, public goods provision problem.

The project is expected to have broader impact because the theory of incomplete information games is heavily used in many applied areas of Economics, as well in some areas of Political Science, Computer Science and Biology.
